content.description: The gorgeous black/brown wall of the west face contains this excellent micro-route, with technical stemming up to and over the roof. A much easier ramp leads to chains up and right, but this will likely finish direct.
content.location: It is on the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description: Start up a right-facing corner, then move straight up (optional green/yellow Alien in slot) to the base of the right arête. Clip both bolts, then crank the crux to easier but still fun climbing.
content.location: It is in the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
Sidewinder is a nice variation pitch on excellent stone. Start on "

Where my Body Dies

", and break left around bolt #4 into the top half of "

Copperhead

".
content.location: It is on the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description: Climb the obvious groove feature at the very uphill end of the wall.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
An inobvious but very good trad line takes the crux of

Mr. Hand

and then breaks right (bolt) to the hanging flake to corners to the upper arête with a remarkable crack in it.
content.protection: Standard trad rack to a #3 Camalot, longer slings are nice, and save a red Camalot for the upper arête + anchor.
content.location: It is in the center of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
This is a decent trad route on the left, which also provides access to the upper anchors for those interested in top-roping the other routes in the wall.

Start below Route 2, and climb up loose-looking but solid rock. Clip the first bolt on 2 to prevent disaster, and traverse straight left to a belay below the obvious, right-angling crack (#1 and #2 Camalots). The main pitch angles up and right (small-medium gear) up the crack with a tricky step right at the break past a loose-sounding flake.
content.location: It is the first route from left to right on the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
Mr. Hand is named in honor of one of the best climbing partners of all time.

The obvious, hands/small hands splitter is pumpy down low (crux) to a hands-off rest, then it goes up progressively easier rock. It is one of the better trad routes in the canyon despite the choss down low.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #4 Camalot + anchor.
content.location: This is in the center of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
This is a good route with several interesting moves.

Start below broken rock and a small, right-facing corner with a bolt at the bottom, and follow the bolt line past a delicate crux up and left past the overlap. A few small cams (pink tri-cam also) calm the run between bolts 4 and 5, but the climbing is easy here. There are some amazing (lucky) holds on this route.
content.location: It is on the left side of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description: The obvious stemming corner is technical and superb. You are home free once you clear the corner, but the upper wall is still fun.
content.location: It is in the center of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description:
This fine route is powerful down low and very delicate up high and requires faith in good, high angle slab shoes.

Take the arête just left of the corner, and crank some powerful moves that get a bit easier to a huge rest at a flake (medium cam). Move up the groove (you can climb a bit right to clip the high bolt), then step left onto the steep, balding slab (crux).
content.location: It is on the left side of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description: Climb an interesting gaston layback boulder problem which trends up and left to a small corner then launch up a technical short arete to a small roof. Here, an interesting sequence of slopers and wide technical compression will engender the start of a pumpy redpoint crux encounter. Gain huge blocky holds and a solid rest before a final run-out 5.8 section to the chains. You could carry or place a mid sized cam which is much less exciting but would protect a large but safe potential fall from easy terrain.
content.location: It is on the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall. The approach is mildly technical either way: crawl through a bouldery maze to a squeeze-hole right above Diamondback, or climb a short, easy bolted traverse on the opposing wall to anchors. Lowering back down is easy for the climber and belayer after climbing/cleaning from your TR.

content.description: This is one way to access the upper tier of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.
content.location: It is on the right side of the gully at the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.

content.description: Climb the steep, overhanging wall on underclings and edges. This is very bouldery and possibly a bit reachy in the crux.
content.location: It is in the center of the Upper Snake Eyes Wall.
